nodes.text: Hypothetical bias in choice experiments (CEs) causes deviations in measures inferred from hypothetical choice data versus more realistic choice data and thereby affects the external validity of CE-derived preference and willingness-to-pay estimates

We performed a systematic multidisciplinary literature review using Web of Science searches, forward/backward citation checks and supplementary searches to compile a core dataset of empirical CE studies that compare hypothetical and more realistic or incentivised choice data (core n = 57–58 studies)
Empirical evidence on hypothetical bias in CEs is mixed overall: some studies find significant bias, others find negligible bias, and many report context- and measure-dependent results

Discipline-specific patterns emerge: health-economics CE studies mostly report negligible or small HB (n≈7 absent/weak), whereas transport CE studies predominantly report significant HB often as lower SP estimates (downward bias), and consumer/environmental domains show mixed but frequently positive/upward bias

A recurring empirical finding is systematic scale differences between hypothetical (SP) and more realistic or revealed-preference (RP) data: SP and RP parameter estimates often differ up to a scale factor, which can affect comparisons of marginal rates and WTP unless scale is accounted for

Hypothetical bias is defined as the deviation in a predefined aggregate or disaggregate measure due to choice data being collected in a hypothetical setting instead of a more realistic (but not necessarily naturalistic) setting, and realism can be ordered into classes I to V from online hypothetical to naturalistic RP

Multiple sources and mechanisms for HB are identified: lack of incentive or payment consequentiality, policy consequentiality, social desirability and warm-glow effects, strategic misrepresentation, hot-cold empathy gaps (context/affect mismatch), cognitive dissonance and design-induced simplification/processing artefacts

Moderating factors influence magnitude and direction of HB: choice context (public vs private, moral/aversive goods), experimental design (within vs between subject, opt-out inclusion), respondent characteristics (gender, familiarity, personality), attribute stakes and payment vehicle, and degree of benchmark realism

Evidence-based mitigation strategies include incentive-aligned designs (financial consequentiality), cheap talk and certainty calibration, improving ecological validity (virtual reality, simulators, tangible stimuli), pivoting SP designs around real-market alternatives, and joint SP-RP estimation or scale correction

Major limitations obstruct synthesis: heterogeneous operational definitions and measurement choices for HB across studies, absence of a universal RP 'gold standard' in many CE contexts, and sparsity of comparable empirical benchmarks in some domains

Conclusion: hypothetical bias is an undeniable concern for CEs but does not render CEs unusable; proper operationalisation of HB, context-aware testing across degrees of realism, scale-adjusted comparisons, and targeted mitigation can preserve CE usefulness for policy and valuation
